newsitem.title: UK: South Africa, Australia to be Saudi suppliers.
newsitem.headline: South Africa, Australia to be Saudi suppliers.

text.p: South Africa and Australia are expected to be the two main suppliers of raw sugar to feed Saudi Arabia's new refinery at Jeddah, the refinery's operator said on Wednesday.
The refinery, which has an annual refining capacity of 500,000 tonnes, is scheduled to come on stream in the first quarter of 1997 after an initial pre-commissioning phase.

"Reliability of supply is very important to us," Mohammad Hassan Ajlan, general manager of the United Sugar Company (USC), told Reuters at a seminar hosted by the International Sugar Organization (ISO).
He added that USC was holding talks with South Africa with a view to signing it up as another long-term supplier. The refinery is due to receive its first shipment of Australian raws later this year.
British trade house Tate & Lyle is to be the USC's raw sugar purchasing agent during the initial period of the refinery's operation and Ajlan said the contract was expcetd to last for about a year.

"It depends on how it goes, it could go on for longer if necessary. Tate & Lyle will go to the market and get the best deal," he said, adding that the London-based company would also be engaged in training operations.
Ajlan said the refinery would introduce a new concept of bulk sugar delivery to the domestic market's industrial users with 25-tonne containers.

As far as potential exports from the refinery were concerned, first target markets were neighbouring countries such as Yemen and Jordan, traditional buyers of European Union sugars, possibly followed by Kuwait and Bahrein, he said.
